Text: Digital image of the original in: The Hague, Koninklijke Bibliotheek, 76 F 5.

Headline: Destruccio Iherosolime
Text:
An imaginary view of the destruction of Jerusalem. Shows the Temple ablaze.
The map is the same as in the first Latin edition, except added title in German.
From: Schedel, Hartmann. Liber chronicarum. German. Nuernberg. Anton Koberger, 1493. Fol.LXIIII. The illustrations and the maps are cut in wood by Michael Wolgemut

Headline: Ierusalem ciuitas sancta, olim metropolis regni Iudaici, hodie uero colonia Turcae
Text:
View
From: Muenster, Sebastian. Cosmographia universalis, Basel, Henricus Petri, 1550, p.1015-1018
At the bottom text partly related to this view and partly about Jericho. On the first verso there are 11 lines of Hebrew text in praise of Jerusalem entitled: "Civitas Iervsale......" On the second verso an imaginary view of Acco in text
The place names on the map are in German. The title and the descriptive text are in Latin

Headline: Jerusalem die heilige vierecket Statt in Grundt gelegt mit allen namhafften Orten...
Text:
An imaginary plan
From: Reissner, Adam. Jerusalem, die alte Haubtstat der Jueden. Franckfurt am Main, 1563. The map is included twice in the book: In pt. 1, B iiii, between folio IX and X, and in pt. 2, H ii, between folio XXXIX and XL.

Headline: Hierusalem
Text:
On the map mistakenly the orientation is reversed
View of modern Jerusalem seen from the east

The map is an exact copy of Braun-Hogenberg's plan of Jeruslame after De Jode-Laicstein

Text:
An imaginary plan
Published at the end of the 16th century. Probably drawn after the Geneva Bible, 1560, for the understanding of the III Chapter of Nehemia's Book

Plan

Text: A reduced plan of Jerusalem after Villalpando

Headline: De Heylige en wytvermaerde stadt Ierusalem, eerst genaemt Salem
Text:
Plan
From a Dutch Bible. Den Haag, 1646. "Dese Kaerte wert gestelt voor het 3 Cap. Nehemia".
At bottom centre a fishing boy is added. Without text on verso.

Plan

Headline: Iherusalem Turcis Cusembareich. Nazareth. Ramma
Text:
Three views on the same plate. At the top a bird's eye view of modern Jerusalem seen from the east. 211x472 mm.; underneath two small views of Nazareth and Ramleh 138 x232 mm. each.
Latin text on both sides of verso, describing Jerusalem, Nazareth and Ramleh.
From: Jansson, Jan. Illustriorum Hispaniae urbium tabulae. Amsterdam, 1657. Part II, Folio D.
Drawn after Reuwich-Breydenbach with some changes.
